concept.title: Overview
concept.shortdesc: Each feature control frame consists of at least two compartments. The first compartment contains a geometric tolerance symbol that indicates the geometric characteristic to which the tolerance is applied, such as location, orientation, or form. For example, a form tolerance may indicate the flatness or roundness of a surface. The geometric tolerance symbols and their characteristics are shown in the following.

conbody.p: Circularity or roundness : Form Straightness : Form
Profile of a surface : Profile Profile of a line : Profile

The tolerance value can then be followed by primary, secondary, and tertiary datum reference letters, along with the material conditions of each datum. Datumreference letters are generally used as reference tolerances to one of up to three perpendicular planes fromwhich a measurement is made, although datum reference letters can also indicate an exact point or axis.
A feature control frame contains symbols that represent location, orientation, form, profile and runout
that apply to a tolerance. Form tolerances control straightness, circularity, flatness, and cylindricity; profiles control surface and line.

Most editing commands can change feature control frames, and these feature control frames can be snapped to with the object snap. You can also use grips to edit geometric tolerances. Unlike dimensions and leaders, geometric objects are not associated with geometric objects.
